snippet: German leaders have not provided details of a potential deal, but it would likely mean an expansion of executive power in Brussels over fiscal targets in member states.
abstract: Germany, pressed by European banking crisis and turmoil in the markets, indicates that it is prepared to accept a grand bargain that will provide greater support for its most indebted euro zone partners in exchange for more centralized control over government spending in Europe; potential deal will likely mean an expansion of executive power in Brussels over fiscal targets in member states and supervision of their banks, along with Europewide deposit insurance.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by David Jolly from Paris, Paul Geitner from Brussels, Jack Ewing from Frankfurt, and Annie Lowery from Washington.

lead_paragraph: German leaders have not provided details of a potential deal, but it would likely mean an expansion of executive power in Brussels over fiscal targets in member states.

headline.seo: Germany Open to Deal on Pooling Euro Debt, With Limits
headline.main: Germany Is Open to Pooling Debt, With Conditions
headline.print_headline: Germany Open To a Debt Pool, With Controls
